{{Use British English|date=October 2012}} '''Asymmetric hydrogenation''' is a [[chemical reaction]] that adds two atoms of [[Hydrogen atom|hydrogen]] preferentially to one of two faces of an [[Saturation (chemistry)|unsaturated]] substrate molecule, such as an alkene or ketone. The selectivity derives from the manner that the substrate binds to the chiral [[catalysts]]. In jargon, this binding transmits spatial information (what chemists refer to as [[chirality]]) from the catalyst to the target, favoring the product as a single [[enantiomer]]. This [[enzyme]]-like selectivity is particularly applied to bioactive products such as [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceutical agents]] and [[agrochemicals]]. [[File:Generic Asymmetric Hydrogenation.png|center|400px]]
{{center|A generic asymmetric hydrogenation of N-acetyl dehydroaminoacids}} == History == In 1956 a [[heterogeneous]] catalyst made of [[palladium]] deposited on silk was shown to effect asymmetric hydrogenation.{{cite journal | last1 = Akabori | first1 = S. | last2 = Sakurai | first2 = S. | last3 = Izumi | first3 = Y. | last4 = Fujii | first4 = Y. | title = An Asymmetric Catalyst | doi = 10.1038/178323b0 | journal = Nature | volume = 178 | issue = 4528 | pages = 323 | year = 1956 | pmid = 13358737| pmc = | bibcode = 1956Natur.178..323A }} Later, in 1968, the groups of [[William Standish Knowles|William Knowles]] and [[Leopold Horner]] independently published the examples of asymmetric hydrogenation using a [[homogeneous catalyst]]s. While exhibiting only modest [[enantiomeric excess]]es, these early reactions demonstrated feasibility. By 1972, enantiomeric excess of 90% was achieved, and the first industrial synthesis of the [[Parkinson's]] drug [[L-DOPA]] commenced using this technology.[[File:3,4-Dihydroxy-L-phenylalanin (Levodopa).svg|thumb|150px|L-DOPA]] The field of asymmetric hydrogenation continued to experience a number of notable advances. [[Henri Kagan]] developed [[DIOP]], an easily prepared C2-symmetric diphosphine that gave high ee's in certain reactions. [[Ryōji Noyori]] introduced the [[ruthenium]]-based catalysts for the asymmetric hydrogenated polar substrates, such as ketones and aldehydes. The introduction of [[Asymmetric hydrogenation#P,N and P,O ligands|P,N ligands]] then further expanded the scope of the C2-symmetric ligands, although they are not fundamentally superior to chiral ligands lacking [[Molecular Symmetry|rotational symmetry]].{{cite journal | last1 = Pfaltz | first1 = A. | title = Asymmetric Catalysis Special Feature Part II: Design of chiral ligands for asymmetric catalysis: From C2-symmetric P,P- and N,N-ligands to sterically and electronically nonsymmetrical P,N-ligands | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0307152101 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 101 | issue = 16 | pages = 5723–5726 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = 395974| bibcode = 2004PNAS..101.5723P }} Today, asymmetric hydrogenation is a routine methodology in laboratory and industrial scale organic chemistry. The importance of '''asymmetric hydrogenation''' was recognized by the 2001 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] awarded to [[William Standish Knowles]] and [[Ryōji Noyori]]. == Mechanism == Two major [[reaction mechanism|mechanisms]] have been proposed for catalytic hydrogenation with [[rhodium]] complexes: the '''unsaturated mechanism''' and the '''dihydride mechanism'''. While distinguishing between the two mechanisms is difficult, the difference between the two for asymmetric hydrogenation is relatively unimportant since both converge to a common intermediate before any stereochemical information is transferred to the product molecule.{{cite journal | last1 = Gridnev | first1 = I. D. | last2 = Imamoto | first2 = T. | doi = 10.1021/ar030156e | title = On the Mechanism of Stereoselection in Rh-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation: A General Approach for Predicting the Sense of Enantioselectivity | journal = Accounts of Chemical Research | volume = 37 | issue = 9 | pages = 633–644 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15379579| pmc = }} [[File:Convergent Mechanisms for Asymmetric Hydrogenation.svg|300px|center]]
{{center|Proposed mechanisms for asymmetric hydrogenation}}
The preference for producing one enantiomer instead of another in these reactions is often explained in terms of [[steric hindrance|steric]] interactions between the [[ligand]] and the [[prochiral]] substrate. Consideration of these interactions has led to the development of quadrant diagrams where "blocked" areas are denoted with a shaded box, while "open" areas are left unfilled. In the modeled reaction, large groups on an incoming [[olefin]] will tend to orient to fill the open areas of the diagram, while smaller groups will be directed to the blocked areas and hydrogen delivery will then occur to the back face of the olefin, fixing the [[stereochemistry]]. Note that only part of the chiral phosphine ligand is shown for the sake of clarity. [[File:Quadrants Diagram for Asymmetric Hydrogenation.tif|center|600px|alt=Comparative chemical diagrams]]
{{Center|Quadrant model for asymmetric hydrogenation}} == Metals == === {{anchor|Platinum Group Metals}}Platinum-group metals === [[Rhodium]], the first metal to be used in a homogeneous asymmetric hydrogenation,{{cite journal | last1 = Knowles | first1 = W. S. | last2 = Sabacky | first2 = M. J. | doi = 10.1039/C19680001445 | title = Catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation employing a soluble, optically active, rhodium complex | journal = Chemical Communications (London) | issue = 22 | pages = 1445 | year = 1968 | pmid = | pmc = }} continues to be widely used. Targets for asymmetric hydrogenation with rhodium generally require a coordinating group close to the [[Alkene|olefin]]. While this requirement is a limitation, many classes of substrates possess such functionalization, e.g. unsaturated amides.{{cite journal | last1 = Pilkington | first1 = C. | last2 = Lennon | first2 = I. | doi = 10.1055/s-2003-40871 | title = The Application of Asymmetric Hydrogenation for the Manufacture of Pharmaceutical Intermediates:The Need for Catalyst Diversity | journal = Synthesis | volume = 2003 | issue = 11 | pages = 1639 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }} The [[Noyori asymmetric hydrogenation]] is based on [[ruthenium]].{{cite journal | last1 = Miyashita | first1 = A. | last2 = Yasuda | first2 = A. | last3 = Takaya | first3 = H. | last4 = Toriumi | first4 = K. | last5 = Ito | first5 = T. | last6 = Souchi | first6 = T. | last7 = Noyori | first7 = R. | doi = 10.1021/ja00547a020 | title = Synthesis of 2,2'-bis(diphenylphosphino)-1,1'-binaphthyl (BINAP), an atropisomeric chiral bis(triaryl)phosphine, and its use in the rhodium(I)-catalyzed asymmetric hydrogenation of .alpha.-(acylamino)acrylic acids | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 102 | issue = 27 | pages = 7932 | year = 1980 | pmid = | pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Noyori | first1 = R. | last2 = Ohkuma | first2 = T. | last3 = Kitamura | first3 = M. | last4 = Takaya | first4 = H. | last5 = Sayo | first5 = N. | last6 = Kumobayashi | first6 = H. | last7 = Akutagawa | first7 = S. | doi = 10.1021/ja00253a051 | title = Asymmetric hydrogenation of .beta.-keto carboxylic esters. A practical, purely chemical access to .beta.-hydroxy esters in high enantiomeric purity | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 109 | issue = 19 | pages = 5856 | year = 1987 | pmid = | pmc = }} Subsequent work has expanded upon Noyori's original catalyst template, leading to the inclusion of traditionally difficult substrates like ''t''-butyl ketones{{cite journal | title = Asymmetric Hydrogenation of ''tert''-Alkyl Ketones|first1=Takeshi |last1=Ohkuma |first2=Christian A. |last2=Sandoval |first3=Rajagopal |last3=Srinivasan |first4=Quinghong |last4=Lin |first5=Yinmao |last5=Wei |first6=Kilian |last6=Muñiz |first7=Ryoji |last7=Noyori | date= 2005-06-01 | doi = 10.1021/ja052071 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 127 | issue = 23 | publisher = American Chemical Society | issn = 0002-7863 }} and 1-tetralones{{cite journal | last1 = Ohkuma | first1 = T. | last2 = Hattori | first2 = T. | last3 = Ooka | first3 = H. | last4 = Inoue | first4 = T. | last5 = Noyori | first5 = R. | title = BINAP/1,4-Diamine−Ruthenium(II) Complexes for Efficient Asymmetric Hydrogenation of 1-Tetralones and Analogues | doi = 10.1021/ol049157c | journal = Organic Letters | volume = 6 | issue = 16 | pages = 2681–2683 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15281743| pmc = }} as viable substrates for hydrogenation with ruthenium catalysts. Transfer hydrogenation based on the Ru and Ts[[DPEN]] has also enjoyed commercial success.{{cite journal | last1 = Ikariya | first1 = T. | last2 = Blacker | first2 = A. J. | doi = 10.1021/ar700134q | title = Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of Ketones with Bifunctional Transition Metal-Based Molecular Catalysts† | journal = Accounts of Chemical Research | volume = 40 | issue = 12 | pages = 1300–1308 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17960897| pmc = }} [[Iridium]] catalysts are useful for a number of "non-traditional" substrates for which good catalysts had not been found with Ru and Rh.{{cite journal | last1 = Church | first1 = T. L. | last2 = Andersson | first2 = P. G. | doi = 10.1016/j.ccr.2007.09.015 | title = Iridium catalysts for the asymmetric hydrogenation of olefins with nontraditional functional substituents | journal = Coordination Chemistry Reviews | volume = 252 | issue = 5–7 | pages = 513 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }} Unfunctionalized olefins{{cite journal | last1 = Lightfoot | first1 = A. | last2 = Schnider | first2 = P. | last3 = Pfaltz | first3 = A. | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1521-3773(19981102)37:20<2897::AID-ANIE2897>3.0.CO;2-8 | title = Enantioselective Hydrogenation of Olefins with Iridium-Phosphanodihydrooxazole Catalysts | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 37 | issue = 20 | pages = 2897 | year = 1998 | pmid = | pmc = }} are the archetypal case, but other examples including ketones{{cite journal | last1 = Xie | first1 = J. H. | last2 = Liu | first2 = X. Y. | last3 = Xie | first3 = J. B. | last4 = Wang | first4 = L. X. | last5 = Zhou | first5 = Q. L. | title = An Additional Coordination Group Leads to Extremely Efficient Chiral Iridium Catalysts for Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Ketones | doi = 10.1002/anie.201102710 | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 50 | issue = 32 | pages = 7329 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21751315| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Pfaltz | first1 = A. | last2 = Blankenstein | first2 = J. R. | last3 = Hilgraf | first3 = R. | last4 = Hörmann | first4 = E. | last5 = McIntyre | first5 = S. | last6 = Menges | first6 = F. | last7 = Schönleber | first7 = M. | last8 = Smidt | first8 = S. P. | last9 = Wüstenberg | first9 = B. | doi = 10.1002/adsc.200390027 | last10 = Zimmermann | first10 = N. | title = Iridium-Catalyzed Enantioselective Hydrogenation of Olefins | journal = Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis | volume = 345 | issue = 12 | pages = 33 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }} exist. A common difficulty with iridium-based catalyst is their tendency to [[Trimer (chemistry)|trimerize]] in solution. The use of a [[Non-coordinating anion|BAr{{su|p=F|b=4}}− anions]] has proven to be the most widely applicable solution to the aggregation problem.{{cite journal | last1 = Cui | first1 = X. | last2 = Burgess | first2 = K. | doi = 10.1021/cr0500131 | title = Catalytic Homogeneous Asymmetric Hydrogenations of Largely Unfunctionalized Alkenes | journal = Chemical Reviews | volume = 105 | issue = 9 | pages = 3272–3296 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16159153| pmc = }} Other strategies to enhance catalyst stability include the addition of an additional coordinating arm to the chiral ligand, increasing the steric bulk of the ligand,{{cite journal | last1 = Xu | first1 = Y. | last2 = Mingos | first2 = D. M. P. | last3 = Brown | first3 = J. M. | title = Crabtree's catalyst revisited; Ligand effects on stability and durability | doi = 10.1039/B711979H | journal = Chemical Communications | issue = 2 | pages = 199 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }} using a [[dendrimer]]ic ligand,{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = Z. J. | last2 = Deng | first2 = G. J. | last3 = Li | first3 = Y. | last4 = He | first4 = Y. M. | last5 = Tang | first5 = W. J. | last6 = Fan | first6 = Q. H. | doi = 10.1021/ol0631410 | title = Enantioselective Hydrogenation of Quinolines Catalyzed by Ir(BINAP)-Cored Dendrimers: Dramatic Enhancement of Catalytic Activity | journal = Organic Letters | volume = 9 | issue = 7 | pages = 1243–1246 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17328554| pmc = }} increasing the rigidity of the ligand,{{cite journal | last1 = Zhu | first1 = S. F. | last2 = Xie | first2 = J. B. | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Y. Z. | last4 = Li | first4 = S. | last5 = Zhou | first5 = Q. L. | title = Well-Defined Chiral Spiro Iridium/Phosphine−Oxazoline Cationic Complexes for Highly Enantioselective Hydrogenation of Imines at Ambient Pressure | doi = 10.1021/ja063444p | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 128 | issue = 39 | pages = 12886–12891 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17002383| pmc = }} immobilizing the ligand,{{cite journal | last1 = Blaser | first1 = H. U. | last2 = Pugin | first2 = B. T. | last3 = Spindler | first3 = F. | last4 = Togni | first4 = A. | title = Enantioselective imine hydrogenation with Ir diphosphine catalysts: Fighting deactivation | doi = 10.1016/S1631-0748(02)01391-7 | journal = Comptes Rendus Chimie | volume = 5 | issue = 5 | pages = 379 | year = 2002 | pmid = | pmc = }} and using heterobimetallic systems (with iridium as one of the metals). === {{anchor|Base Metals}}Base metals === [[Iron]] is a popular research target for many catalytic processes, owing largely to its low cost and low toxicity relative to other transition metals.{{cite journal | last1 = Enthaler | first1 = S. | last2 = Junge | first2 = K. | last3 = Beller | first3 = M. | doi = 10.1002/anie.200800012 | title = Sustainable Metal Catalysis with Iron: From Rust to a Rising Star? | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 47 | issue = 18 | pages = 3317 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18412184| pmc = }} Asymmetric hydrogenation methods using iron have been realized, although in terms of rates and selectivity, they are inferior to catalysts based on precious metals.{{cite journal | last1 = Mikhailine | first1 = A. | last2 = Lough | first2 = A. J. | last3 = Morris | first3 = R. H. | doi = 10.1021/ja809493h | title = Efficient Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of Ketones Catalyzed by an Iron Complex Containing a P−N−N−P Tetradentate Ligand Formed by Template Synthesis | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 131 | issue = 4 | pages = 1394–1395 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19133772| pmc = }} In some cases, structurally ill-defined [[nanoparticles]] have proven to be the active species ''in situ'' and the modest selectivity observed may result from their uncontrolled geometries.{{cite journal | last1 = Sonnenberg | first1 = J. F. | last2 = Coombs | first2 = N. | last3 = Dube | first3 = P. A. | last4 = Morris | first4 = R. H. | title = Iron Nanoparticles Catalyzing the Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of Ketones | doi = 10.1021/ja211658t | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 134 | issue = 13 | pages = 5893–5899 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22448656| pmc = }} == {{anchor|Ligand Classes}}Ligand classes == === {{anchor|Phosphine Ligands}}Phosphine ligands === Chiral [[Phosphine#Phosphines|phosphine]] ligands, especially [[C2-Symmetric ligands|C2-symmetric ligand]]s, are the source of chirality in most asymmetric hydrogenation catalysts. Of these the [[BINAP]] ligand is well-known, as a result of its Nobel Prize-winning application in the [[Noyori asymmetric hydrogenation]].{{cite journal | last1 = Noyori | first1 = R. | title = Asymmetric Catalysis: Science and Opportunities (Nobel Lecture 2001) | doi = 10.1002/adsc.200390002 | journal = Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis | volume = 345 | issue = 12 | pages = 15–41 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }} Chiral phosphine ligands can be generally classified as [[Denticity|mono- or bidentate]]. They can be further classified according to the location of the stereogenic centre – phosphorus vs the organic substituents. Ligands with a C2 symmetry element have been particularly popular, in part because the presence of such an element reduces the possible binding conformations of a substrate to a metal-ligand complex dramatically (often resulting in exceptional enantioselectivity).{{cite journal | last1 = Whitesell | first1 = J. K. | title = C2 symmetry and asymmetric induction | doi = 10.1021/cr00097a012 | journal = Chemical Reviews | volume = 89 | issue = 7 | pages = 1581–1590 | year = 1989 | pmid = | pmc = }} ==== Chiral monophosphine, monodentate ligands ==== Monophosphine-type ligands were among the first to appear in asymmetric hydrogenation, e.g., the ligand CAMP.{{cite journal | last1 = Knowles | first1 = W. S. | last2 = Sabacky | first2 = M. J. | last3 = Vineyard | first3 = B. D. | title = Catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation | doi = 10.1039/C39720000010 | journal = Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications | pages = 10 | year = 1972 | pmid = | pmc = | issue=1}} Continued research into these types of ligands has explored both P-alkyl and P-heteroatom bonded ligands, with P-heteroatom ligands like the phosphites and [[phosphoramidite]]s generally achieving more impressive results.{{cite journal | last1 = Jerphagnon | first1 = T. | last2 = Renaud | first2 = J. L. | last3 = Bruneau | first3 = C. | doi = 10.1016/j.tetasy.2004.04.037 | title = Chiral monodentate phosphorus ligands for rhodium-catalyzed asymmetric hydrogenation | journal = Tetrahedron: Asymmetry | volume = 15 | issue = 14 | pages = 2101 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }} Structural classes of ligands that have been successful include those based on the binapthyl structure of MonoPHOS {{cite journal | last1 = Van Den Berg | first1 = M. | last2 = Minnaard | first2 = A. J. | last3 = Schudde | first3 = E. P. | last4 = Van Esch | first4 = J. | last5 = De Vries | first5 = A. H. M. | last6 = De Vries | first6 = J. G. | last7 = Feringa | first7 = B. L. | doi = 10.1021/ja002507f | title = Highly Enantioselective Rhodium-Catalyzed Hydrogenation with Monodentate Ligands | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 122 | issue = 46 | pages = 11539 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }} or the spiro ring system of SiPHOS.{{cite journal | last1 = Fu | first1 = Y. | last2 = Xie | first2 = J. H. | last3 = Hu | first3 = A. G. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = H. | last5 = Wang | first5 = L. X. | last6 = Zhou | first6 = Q. L. | doi = 10.1039/B109827F | title = Novel monodentate spiro phosphorus ligands for rhodium-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions | journal = Chemical Communications | issue = 5 | pages = 480 | year = 2002 | pmid = | pmc = }} Notably, these monodentate ligands can be used in combination with each other to achieve a synergistic improvement in enantioselectivity;{{cite journal | last1 = Reetz | first1 = M. T. | last2 = Sell | first2 = T. | last3 = Meiswinkel | first3 = A. | last4 = Mehler | first4 = G. | title = A New Principle in Combinatorial Asymmetric Transition-Metal Catalysis: Mixtures of Chiral Monodentate P Ligands | doi = 10.1002/anie.200390209 | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 42 | issue = 7 | pages = 790 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12596201| pmc = }} something that is not possible with the [[diphosphine ligand]]s. {{triple image|center|ChiralMonophosphine2.tif|125|CAMP.tif|100|ChiralMonophosphine.tif|160|A [[ferrocene]] derivative|The CAMP ligand|A [[1,1'-Bi-2-naphthol|BINOL]] derivative|A chiral monophosphine derived from ferrocene|The historically important CAMP ligand|A chiral monophosphine derived from BINOL}} ==== Chiral diphosphine ligands ==== The diphosphine ligands have received considerably more attention than the monophosphines and, perhaps as a consequence, have a much longer list of achievement. This class includes the first ligand to achieve high selectivity ([[DIOP]]), the first ligand to be used in industrial asymmetric synthesis ([[DIPAMP]]{{cite journal | last1 = Vineyard | first1 = B. D. | last2 = Knowles | first2 = W. S. | last3 = Sabacky | first3 = M. J. | last4 = Bachman | first4 = G. L. | last5 = Weinkauff | first5 = D. J. | title = Asymmetric hydrogenation. Rhodium chiral bisphosphine catalyst | doi = 10.1021/ja00460a018 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 99 | issue = 18 | pages = 5946 | year = 1977 | pmid = | pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Knowles | first1 = W. S. | last2 = Sabacky | first2 = M. J. | last3 = Vineyard | first3 = B. D. | last4 = Weinkauff | first4 = D. J. | title = Asymmetric hydrogenation with a complex of rhodium and a chiral bisphosphine | doi = 10.1021/ja00842a058 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 97 | issue = 9 | pages = 2567 | year = 1975 | pmid = | pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Knowles | first1 = W. S. | title = Asymmetric Hydrogenations (Nobel Lecture) | doi = 10.1002/1521-3773(20020617)41:12<1998::AID-ANIE1998>3.0.CO;2-8 | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 41 | issue = 12 | pages = 1998–2007 | year = 2002 | pmid = | pmc = }}) and what is likely the best known chiral ligand (BINAP). Chiral diphosphine ligands are now ubiquitous in asymmetric hydrogenation. [[File:Historic Diphosphines.tif|center|500px|alt=Three chemical diagrams]]
{{center|Historically important diphosphine ligands}} ==== {{anchor|Chiral P,N and P,O ligands}}P,N and P,O ligands ==== {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Generic PHOX Ligand.tif | caption1 = Generic PHOX ligand architecture | width1 = {{#expr: (31.5*3) round 0 }} | image2 = PO Ligand Asymmetric Hydrogenation.tif | caption2 = Effective ligand for various asymmetric-hydrogenation processes | width2 = {{#expr: (48.2*3) round 0 }} }} The use of P,N ligands in asymmetric hydrogenation can be traced to the C2 symmetric [[bisoxazoline ligand]].{{cite journal | last1 = Müller | first1 = D. | last2 = Umbricht | first2 = G. | last3 = Weber | first3 = B. | last4 = Pfaltz | first4 = A. | title = C2-Symmetric 4,4',5,5'-Tetrahydrobi(oxazoles) and 4,4',5,5'-Tetrahydro-2,2'-methylenebis[oxazoles] as Chiral Ligands for Enantioselective Catalysis Preliminary Communication | doi = 10.1002/hlca.19910740123 | journal = Helvetica Chimica Acta | volume = 74 | pages = 232 | year = 1991 | pmid = | pmc = }} However, these symmetric ligands were soon superseded by mono([[oxazoline]]) ligands whose lack of C2 symmetry has in no way limits their efficacy in asymmetric catalysis.{{cite journal | last1 = Helmchen | first1 = G. N. | last2 = Pfaltz | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1021/ar9900865 | title = PhosphinooxazolinesA New Class of Versatile, Modular P,N-Ligands for Asymmetric Catalysis | journal = Accounts of Chemical Research | volume = 33 | issue = 6 | pages = 336–345 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10891051| pmc = }} Such ligands generally consist of an achiral nitrogen-containing heterocycle that is functionalized with a pendant phosphorus-containing arm, although both the exact nature of the heterocycle and the chemical environment phosphorus center has varied widely. No single structure has emerged as consistently effective with a broad range of substrates, although certain [[Privileged ligand#Privileged ligands|privileged]] structures (like the phosphine-oxazoline or [[Phosphinooxazolines|PHOX]] architecture) have been established.{{cite journal | last1 = Franzke | first1 = A. | last2 = Pfaltz | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1002/chem.201003314 | title = Zwitterionic Iridium Complexes with P,N-Ligands as Catalysts for the Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Alkenes | journal = Chemistry: A European Journal | volume = 17 | issue = 15 | pages = 4131 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }} Moreover, within a narrowly defined substrate class the performance of metallic complexes with chiral P,N ligands can closely approach perfect conversion and selectivity in systems otherwise very difficult to target.{{cite journal | last1 = Maurer | first1 = F. | last2 = Huch | first2 = V. | last3 = Ullrich | first3 = A. | last4 = Kazmaier | first4 = U. | title = Development of Catalysts for the Stereoselective Hydrogenation of α,β-Unsaturated Ketones | doi = 10.1021/jo300246c | journal = The Journal of Organic Chemistry | volume = 77 | issue = 11 | pages = 5139–5143 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22571628| pmc = }} Certain complexes derived from chelating P-O ligands have shown promising results in the hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated ketones and esters.{{cite journal | last1 = Rageot | first1 = D. | last2 = Woodmansee | first2 = D. H. | last3 = Pugin | first3 = B. T. | last4 = Pfaltz | first4 = A. | title = Proline-Based P,O Ligand/Iridium Complexes as Highly Selective Catalysts: Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Trisubstituted Alkenes | doi = 10.1002/anie.201104105 | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 50 | issue = 41 | pages = 9598 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21882320| pmc = }} ==== {{anchor|NHC Ligands}}NHC ligands ==== [[File:Burgess's Asymmetric Hydrogenation Catalyst.tif|thumb|right|200px|Catalyst developed by [[Kevin Burgess (chemist)|Burgess]] for asymmetric hydrogenation|alt=Chemical diagram]] Simple [[N-heterocyclic carbene]] (NHC)-based ligands have proven impractical for asymmetrical hydrogenation. Some C,N ligands combine an NHC with a chiral oxazoline to give a chelating ligand.{{cite journal | last1 = Perry | first1 = M. C. | last2 = Cui | first2 = X. | last3 = Powell | first3 = M. T. | last4 = Hou | first4 = D. R. | last5 = Reibenspies | first5 = J. H. | last6 = Burgess | first6 = K. | doi = 10.1021/ja028142b | title = Optically Active Iridium Imidazol-2-ylidene-oxazoline Complexes: Preparation and Use in Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Arylalkenes | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 125 | issue = 1 | pages = 113–123 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12515512| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Nanchen | first1 = S. | last2 = Pfaltz | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1002/chem.200501500 | title = Synthesis and Application of ChiralN-Heterocyclic Carbene–Oxazoline Ligands: Iridium-Catalyzed Enantioselective Hydrogenation | journal = Chemistry: A European Journal | volume = 12 | issue = 17 | pages = 4550 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }} NHC-based ligands of the first type have been generated as large libraries from the reaction of smaller libraries of individual NHCs and oxazolines. NHC-based catalysts featuring a bulky seven-membered metallocycle on iridium have been applied to the catalytic hydrogenation of unfunctionalized olefins and [[Vinyl group|vinyl]] ether alcohols with conversions and ee's in the high 80s or 90s.{{cite journal | last1 = Zhu | first1 = Y. | last2 = Burgess | first2 = K. | doi = 10.1002/adsc.200700546 | title = Iridium-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Vinyl Ethers | journal = Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis | volume = 350 | issue = 7–8 | pages = 979 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }} The same system has been applied to the synthesis of a number of aldol,{{cite journal | last1 = Zhao | first1 = J. | last2 = Burgess | first2 = K. | doi = 10.1021/ol900308w | title = Aldol-Type Chirons from Asymmetric Hydrogenations of Trisubstituted pages = 3803 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21442699| pmc = }} == {{anchor|Linear Substrates}}Acyclic substrates == Acyclic unsaturated substrates ([[olefins]], [[ketones]], [[enamine]]s [[imines]]) represents the most common prochiral substrates. Substrates that are particularly amenable to asymmetric hydrogenation often feature a polar functional group adjacent to the site to be hydrogenates. In the absence of this functional) group, catalysis often results in low ee's. For unfunctionalized olefins, iridium with P,N-based ligands) have proven successful catalysts. Catalyst utility within this category is unusually narrow; consequently, many different categories of solved and unsolved catalytic problems have developed. 1,1-disubstituted, 1,2-diaryl trisubstituted, 1,1,2-trialkyl and tetrasubstituted olefins represent classes that have been investigated separately,{{cite journal | last1 = Pàmies | first1 = O. | last2 = Andersson | first2 = P. {{Center|Example of asymmetric hydrogenation of unfunctionalized olefins}}
[[File:ChiralMonodentate.png|thumb|Chiral phosphoramidite and phosphonite ligands used in the asymmetric hydrogenation of enamines.]] Conversely to the case of olefins, asymmetric hydrogenation of enamines has favoured diphosphine-type ligands; excellent results have been achieved with both iridium- and rhodium-based systems. However, even the best systems often suffer from low ee's and a lack of generality. Certain [[pyrrolidine]]-derived enamines of aromatic ketones are amenable to asymmetrically hydrogenation with cationic rhodium(I) phosphonite systems, and I2 and acetic acid system with ee values usually above 90% and potentially as high as 99.9%.{{cite journal | last1 = Hou | first1 = G. H. | last2 = Xie | first2 = J. H. | last3 = Wang | first3 = L. X. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = Q. L. | title = Highly Efficient Rh(I)-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Enamines Using Monodente Spiro Phosphonite Ligands | doi = 10.1021/ja0644778 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 128 | issue = 36 | pages = 11774–11775 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16953614| pmc = }} A similar system using iridium(I) and a very closely related [[phosphoramidite]] ligand is effective for the asymmetric hydrogenation of pyrrolidine-type enamines where the double bond was inside the ring: in other words, of dihydropyrroles.{{cite journal | last1 = Hou | first1 = G. H. | last2 = Xie | first2 = J. H. | last3 = Yan | first3 = P. C. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = Q. L. | title = Iridium-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Cyclic Enamines | doi = 10.1021/ja808358r | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 131 | issue = 4 | pages = 1366–1367 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19132836| pmc = }} In both cases, the enantioselectivity dropped substantially when the ring size was increased from five to six. === {{anchor|Imines and Ketones}}Imines and ketones === [[File:Noyori DiamineCatalyst.png|thumb|Archetype of Noyori's catalysts for asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones]] [[Ketones]] and [[imines]] are related functional groups, and effective technologies for the asymmetric hydrogenation of each are also closely related. Of these, Noyori's ruthenium-chiral diphosphine-diamine system is perhaps one of the best known.{{cite journal | last1 = Ohkuma | first1 = T. | last2 = Ooka | first2 = H. | last3 = Hashiguchi | first3 = S. | last4 = Ikariya | first4 = T. | last5 = Noyori | first5 = R. | title = Practical Enantioselective Hydrogenation of Aromatic Ketones | doi = 10.1021/ja00114a043 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 117 | issue = 9 | pages = 2675 | year = 1995 | pmid = | pmc = }} It can be employed in conjunction with a wide range of phosphines and amines (where the amine may be, but need not be, chiral) and can be easily adjusted for an optimal match with the target substrate, generally achieving [[enantiomeric excess]]es (ee's) above 90%.{{cite journal | last1 = Noyori | first1 = R. | last2 = Ohkuma | first2 = T. | doi = 10.1002/1521-3773(20010105)40:1<40::AID-ANIE40>3.0.CO;2-5 | title = Asymmetric Catalysis by Architectural and Functional Molecular Engineering: Practical Chemo- and Stereoselective Hydrogenation of Ketones | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 40 | issue = 1 | pages = 40–73 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11169691| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Hems | first1 = W. P. | last2 = Groarke | first2 = M. | last3 = Zanotti-Gerosa | first3 = A. | last4 = Grasa | first4 = G. A. | title = \(Bisphosphine) Ru(II) Diamine] Complexes in Asymmetric Hydrogenation: Expanding the Scope of the Diamine Ligand | doi = 10.1021/ar7000233 | journal = Accounts of Chemical Research | volume = 40 | issue = 12 | pages = 1340–1347 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17576143| pmc = }} For carbonyl and imine substrates, end-on, η1 coordination can compete with η2 mode. For η1-bound substrates, the hydrogen-accepting carbon is removed from the catalyst and resists hydrogenation.{{cite journal | last1 = Noyori | first1 = R. | last2 = Yamakawa | first2 = M. | last3 = Hashiguchi | first3 = S. | doi = 10.1021/jo010721w | title = Metal−Ligand Bifunctional Catalysis: A Nonclassical Mechanism for Asymmetric Hydrogen Transfer between Alcohols and Carbonyl Compounds | journal = The Journal of Organic Chemistry | volume = 66 | issue = 24 | pages = 7931–7944 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11722188| pmc = }} Iridium/P,N ligand-based systems are also commonly used for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones and imines. For example, a consistent system for benzylic aryl imines uses the P,N ligand SIPHOX in conjunction with iridium(I) in a cationic complex to achieve asymmetric hydrogenation with ee >90%. One of the most efficient and effective catalysts ever developed for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones, with a [[turnover number]] (TON) up to 4,550,000 and ee up to 99.9%, uses another iridium(I) system with a closely related [[tridentate ligand]]. [[File:Efficient Asymmetric Ketone Hydrogenation with SpiroPAP.png|center|500px|alt=Two chemical diagrams]]
{{center|Highly effective system for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones}} Despite their similarities, the two functional groups are not identical; there are many areas where they diverge significantly. One of these is in the asymmetric hydrogenation of N-unfunctionalized imines to give primary amines. Such species can be difficult to selectively reduce because they tend to exist in complex equilibria of imine and enamine [[tautomers]], as well as (E) and (Z) isomers.{{cite journal | last1 = Yu | first1 = Z. | last2 = Jin | first2 = W. | last3 = Jiang | first3 = Q. | doi = 10.1002/anie.201200963 | title = Brønsted Acid Activation Strategy in Transition-Metal Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of N-Unprotected Imines, Enamines, and N-Heteroaromatic Compounds | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 51 | issue = 25 | pages = 6060 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22577004| pmc = }} One approach to this problem has been to use [[Imine|ketimines]] as their hydrochloride salt and rely on the steric properties of the adjacent alkyl or [[aryl]] groups to allow the catalyst to differentiate between the two [[enantiotopic]] faces of the ketimine.{{cite journal | last1 = Hou | first1 = G. | last2 = Gosselin | first2 = F. | last3 = Li | first3 = W. | last4 = McWilliams | first4 = J. W. | doi = 10.1021/ja903319r | last10 = Zhang | first10 = X. | title = Enantioselective Hydrogenation of N−H Imines | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 131 | issue = 29 | pages = 9882–9883 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19569686| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Hou | first1 = G. | last2 = Tao | first2 = R. | last3 = Sun | first3 = Y. | last4 = Zhang | first4 = X. | last5 = Gosselin | first5 = F. | title = Iridium−Monodentate Phosphoramidite-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Substituted Benzophenone N−H Imines | doi = 10.1021/ja909583s | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 132 | issue = 7 | pages = 2124–2125 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20104899| pmc = }} == {{anchor|Aromatic Substrates}}Aromatic substrates == The asymmetric hydrogenation of [[aromaticity|aromatic]] (especially [[heteroaromatic]]), substrates is a very active field of ongoing research. Catalysts in this field must contend with a number of complicating factors, including the tendency of highly stable aromatic compounds to resist hydrogenation, the potential coordinating (and therefore catalyst-poisoning) abilities of both substrate and product, and the great diversity in substitution patterns that may be present on any one aromatic ring.{{cite journal | last1 = Zhou | first1 = Y. G. | title = Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Heteroaromatic Compounds | doi = 10.1021/ar700094b | journal = Accounts of Chemical Research | volume = 40 | issue = 12 | pages = 1357–1366 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17896823| pmc = }} Of these substrates the most consistent success has been seen with nitrogen-containing heterocycles, where the aromatic ring is often activated either by protonation or by further functionalization of the nitrogen (generally with an electron-withdrawing protecting group). Such strategies are less applicable to oxygen- and sulfur-containing heterocycles, since they are both less basic and less nucleophilic; this additional difficulty may help to explain why few effective methods exist for their asymmetric hydrogenation. === {{anchor|Quinolines, Isoquinolines, and Quinoxalines}}Quinolines, isoquinolines and quinoxalines === Two systems exist for the asymmetric hydrogenation of 2-substituted [[quinolines]] with isolated yields generally greater than 80% and ee values generally greater than 90%. The first is an iridium(I)/chiral phosphine/I2 system, first reported by Zhou ''et al''.{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = W. B. | last2 = Lu | first2 = S. M. | last3 = Yang | first3 = P. The second is an organocatalytic [[transfer hydrogenation]] system based on [[Hantzsch ester]]s and a chiral [[Brønsted acid]]. In this case, the authors envision a mechanism where the isoquinoline is alternately protonated in an activating step, then reduced by conjugate addition of hydride from the Hantzsch ester.{{cite journal| author1 = Rueping| first2 = A.| first3 = T.| title = A highly enantioselective Brønsted acid catalyzed cascade reaction: organocatalytic transfer hydrogenation of quinolines and their application in the synthesis of alkaloids| journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition in English| volume = 45| issue = 22| pages = 3683–3686| year = 2006| pmid = 16639754| doi = 10.1002/anie.200600191| last2 = Antonchick| last3 = Theissmann}} [[File:OrganocatalyticAsymmetricHydrogenation Quinoline.tif|1000px|Several Chemical Diagrams]]
{{center|Proposed organocatalytic mechanism}} Much of the asymmetric hydrogenation chemistry of quinoxalines is closely related to that of the structurally similar [[quinolines]]. Effective (and efficient) results can be obtained with an Ir(I)/phophinite/I2 system{{cite journal | last1 = Tang | first1 = W. | last2 = Xu | first2 = L. | last3 = Fan | first3 = Q. R. | doi = 10.1002/chem.200902907 | title = The First General, Efficient and Highly Enantioselective Reduction of Quinoxalines and Quinoxalinones | journal = Chemistry: A European Journal | volume = 16 | issue = 9 | pages = 2688 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = }} both of which are similar to the systems discussed earlier with regards to [[#Quinolines and Isoquinolines|quinolines]]. === Pyridines === [[Pyridines]] are highly variable substrates for asymmetric reduction (even compared to other heteroaromatics), in that five carbon centers are available for differential substitution on the initial ring. As of October 2012 no method seems to exist that can control all five, although at least one reasonably general method exists. The most-general method of asymmetric pyridine hydrogenation is actually a heterogeneous method, where asymmetry is generated from a chiral oxazolidinone bound to the C2 position of the pyridine. Hydrogenating such functionalized pyridines over a number of different heterogeneous metal catalysts gave the corresponding piperidine with the substituents at C3, C4, and C5 positions in an all-''cis'' geometry, in high yield and excellent enantioselectivity. The oxazolidinone auxiliary is also conveniently cleaved under the hydrogenation conditions.{{cite journal | last1 = Glorius | first1 = F. | last2 = Spielkamp | first2 = N. | last3 = Holle | first3 = S. | last4 = Goddard | first4 = R. | last5 = Lehmann | first5 = C. J. | last2 = Tan | first2 = J. | last3 = Xu | first3 = L. J. | last4 = Lam | first4 = K. H. | last5 = Fan | first5 = Q. H. | last6 = Chan | first6 = A. S. P. | doi = 10.1002/anie.200701158 | title = Organocatalytic Enantioselective Reduction of Pyridines | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 46 | issue = 24 | pages = 4562 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17492817| pmc = }} === Indoles === The asymmetric hydrogenation of [[indole]]s initially focused on N-protected indoles, where the protecting group could serve both to activate the heterocycle to hydrogenation and as a secondary coordination site for the metal. Later work allowed unprotected indoles to be targeted through Brønsted acid activation of the indole. In the initial report on asymmetric indole hydrogenation, N-acetyl 2-substituted indoles could be protected with high yields and ee of 87-95%. 3-substituted indoles were less successful, with hydrolysis of the protecting group outcompeting the hydrogenation of the indole.{{cite journal | last1 = Kuwano | first1 = R. | last2 = Sato | first2 = K. | last3 = Kurokawa | first3 = T. | last4 = Karube | first4 = D. | last5 = Ito | first5 = Y. | title = Catalytic Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Heteroaromatic Compounds, Indoles | doi = 10.1021/ja001271c | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 122 | issue = 31 | pages = 7614 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }} Switching to an N-tosyl protecting group inhibited the hydrolysis reaction and allowed both 2- and 3-substituted indoles to be hydrogenated in high yield and ee.{{cite journal | last1 = Kuwano | first1 = R. | last2 = Kaneda | first2 = K. | last3 = Ito | first3 = T. | last4 = Sato | first4 = K. | last5 = Kurokawa | first5 = T. | last6 = Ito | first6 = Y. | doi = 10.1021/ol049317k | title = Highly Enantioselective Synthesis of Chiral 3-Substituted Indolines by Catalytic Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Indoles | journal = Organic Letters | volume = 6 | issue = 13 | pages = 2213–2215 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15200323| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Kuwano | first1 = R. | last2 = Kashiwabara | first2 = M. | last3 = Sato | first3 = K. | last4 = Ito | first4 = T. | last5 = Kaneda | first5 = K. | last6 = Ito | first6 = Y. | doi = 10.1016/j.tetasy.2006.01.016 | title = Catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation of indoles using a rhodium complex with a chiral bisphosphine ligand PhTRAP | journal = Tetrahedron: Asymmetry | volume = 17 | issue = 4 | pages = 521 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }} The problem with both methods, however, is that N-acetyl and N-tosyl groups require harsh cleavage conditions that might be incompatible with complex substrates. Using an easily cleaved N-Boc group would relieve this problem, and highly effective methods for the asymmetric hydrogenation of such indoles (both 2- and 3-substituted) were soon developed.{{cite journal | last1 = Kuwano | first1 = R. | last2 = Kashiwabara | first2 = M. | doi = 10.1021/ol061039x | title = Ruthenium-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation ofN-Boc-Indoles | journal = Organic Letters | volume = 8 | issue = 12 | pages = 2653–2655 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16737337| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Baeza | first1 = A. | last2 = Pfaltz | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1002/chem.200903105 | title = Iridium-Catalyzed Asymmetric Hydrogenation of N-Protected Indoles | journal = Chemistry: A European Journal | volume = 16 | issue = 7 | pages = 2036 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = }} [[File:Indoles Boc.tif|400px|center|alt=Diagram of chemical process]]
{{center|Method for asymmetric hydrogenation of boc-protected indoles}} Despite these advances in the asymmetric hydrogenation of protected indoles, considerable operational simplicity can be gained by removing the protecting group altogether. This has been achieved with catalytic systems utilizing Brønsted acids to activate the indole. The initial system used a Pd(TFA)2/H8-BINAP system to achieve the enantioselective ''cis''-hydrogenation of 2,3- and 2-substituted indoles with high yield and excellent ee. A similar process, where sequential [[Friedel-Crafts reaction|Friedel-Crafts alkylation]] and asymmetric hydrogenation occur in one pot, allow asymmetric 2,3-substituted indolines to be selectively prepared from 2-substituted indoles in similarly high yields and ee.{{cite journal | last1 = Xiao | first1 = Y. {{center|Sequential alkylation and asymmetric hydrogenation of 2-substituted indoles}} A promising [[Organocatalysis|organocatalytic]] method for the asymmetric hydrogenation of 2,3-substituted indoles utilizing a chiral Lewis base also exists, although the observed ee's are not quite equivalent to those of the metal-based hydrogenations. === Pyrroles === Achieving complete conversion of [[pyrroles]] to [[pyrrolidines]] by asymmetric hydrogenation has so far proven difficult, with partial-hydrogenation products often being observed.{{cite journal | last1 = Kuwano | first1 = R. | last2 = Kashiwabara | first2 = M. | last3 = Ohsumi | first3 = M. | last4 = Kusano | first4 = H. | title = Catalytic Asymmetric Hydrogenation of 2,3,5-Trisubstituted Pyrroles | doi = 10.1021/ja7102422 | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 130 | issue = 3 | pages = 808–809 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18154340| pmc = }}{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = D. S. | last2 = Ye | first2 = Z. S. | last3 = Chen | first3 = Q. A. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = Y. G. | last5 = Yu | first5 = C. B. | last6 = Fan | first6 = H. J. | last7 = Duan | first7 = Y. | doi = 10.1021/ja203190t | title = Highly Enantioselective Partial Hydrogenation of Simple Pyrroles: A Facile Access to Chiral 1-Pyrrolines | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 133 | issue = 23 | pages = 8866–8869 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21591641| pmc = }} Complete enantioselective reduction is possible, with the outcome depending on both the starting substrate and the method. The asymmetric hydrogenation of 2,3,5-substituted pyrroles was achieved by the recognition that such substrates bear the same substitution pattern as 2-substituted indoles, and an asymmetric hydrogenation system that is effective for one of these substrates might be effective for both. Such an analysis led to the development of a ruthenium(I)/phosphine/amine base system for 2,3,5-substituted N-Boc pyrroles that can give either dihydro or tetrahydropyrroles (pyrrolidines), depending on the nature of the pyrrole substituents. An all-phenyl substitution pattern leads to dihydropyrroles in very high yield (>96%) and essentially perfect enantioselectivity. Access to the fully hydrogenated, all-''cis'' dihydropyrrole may then be accessible through diastereoselective heterogeneous hydrogenation. Alkyl substitution may lead to either the dihydro or tetrahydropyrrole, although the yields (>70%) and enantioselectivities (often >90%) generally remain high. The [[regioselectivity]] in both cases appears to be governed by sterics, with the less-substituted double being preferentially hydrogenated. [[File:Asymmetric Hydrogenation of 2,3,5-substituted N-Boc Pyrroles.tif|center|500px]]
{{center|The asymmetric hydrogenation of 2,3,5-substituted N-Boc pyrroles}} Unprotected 2,5-pyrroles may also be hydrogenated asymmetrically by a Brønsted acid/Pd(II)/chiral phosphine-catalyzed method, to give the corresponding 2,5-disubstituted 1-[[pyrrolines]] in roughly 70-80% yield and 80-90% ee. === {{anchor|Oxygen-Containing Heterocycles}}Oxygen-containing heterocycles === The asymmetric hydrogenation of [[furan]]s and [[benzofuran]]s has so far proven challenging.{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = D. S. | last2 = Chen | first2 = Q. A. | last3 = Lu | first3 = S. M. | last4 = Zhou | first4 = Y. G. | title = Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Heteroarenes and Arenes | doi = 10.1021/cr200328h | journal = Chemical Reviews | volume = 112 | issue = 4 | pages = 2557–2590 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22098109| pmc = }} Some Ru-NHC complex catalyze asymmetric hydrogenations of [[benzofuran]]s{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/anie.201107811|title=Ruthenium NHC Catalyzed Highly Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Benzofurans|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|volume=51|issue=7|pages=1710|year=2012|last1=Ortega|first1=Nuria|last2=Urban|first2=Slawomir|last3=Beiring|first3=Bernhard|last4=Glorius|first4=Frank|pmid=22311814}} and furans.{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/anie.201310985|pmid=24554623|title=Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Disubstituted Furans|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|volume=53|issue=33|pages=8751|year=2014|last1=Wysocki|first1=Jędrzej|last2=Ortega|first2=Nuria|last3=Glorius|first3=Frank}} with high levels of enantioinduction. [[File:Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Benzofuran.png|center|400px]]
{{center|The asymmetric hydrogenation of furans and benzofurans}} === {{anchor|Sulfur-Containing Heterocycles}}Sulfur-containing heterocycles === As is the case with oxygen-containing heterocycles, the asymmetric hydrogenation of compounds where sulfur is part of the initial unsaturated [[Pi bond|pi-bonding]] system so far appears to be limited to [[thiophene]]s and [[benzothiophene]]s. The key approach to the asymmetric hydrogenation of these heterocycles involves a ruthenium(II) catalyst and chiral, C2 symmetric [[Persistent carbene|N-heterocyclic carbene]] (NHC). This system appears to possess superb selectivity (ee > 90%) and perfect diastereoselectivity (all ''cis'') if the substrate has a fused (or directly bound) phenyl ring but yields only [[racemic]] product in all other tested cases.{{cite journal | last1 = Urban | first1 = S. | last2 = Beiring | first2 = B. | last3 = Ortega | first3 = N. | last4 = Paul | first4 = D. | last5 = Glorius | first5 = F. | title = Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Thiophenes and Benzothiophenes | doi = 10.1021/ja306622y | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 134 | issue = 37 | pages = 15241–15244 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22934527| pmc = }} [[File:Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Thiophenes.tif|center|450px]]
{{center|The asymmetric hydrogenation of thiophenes and benzothiophenes}} == Heterogeneous catalysis == Research into asymmetric hydrogenation with heterogeneous catalysts has generally focused on three areas. The oldest, dating back to the first asymmetric hydrogenation with palladium deposited on a silk support, involves modifying a metal surface with a chiral molecule, usually one that can be harvested from nature. Alternatively, researchers have used various techniques to attempt to immobilize what would otherwise be homogeneous catalysts on heterogeneous supports or have used synthetic organic ligands and metal sources to build chiral [[metal-organic framework]]s (MOFs). [[File:Cinchonidine2d.png|thumb|100px|[[Cinchonidine]], one of the cinchona alkaloids]] The greatest successes in chiral modification of metal surfaces have come from the use of [[cinchona]] [[alkaloids]], though numerous other classes of natural products have been evaluated. These alkaloids have been shown to enhance the rate of substrate hydrogenation by 10–100 times, such that less than one molecule of cinchona alkaloid is needed for every reactive site on the metal and, in fact, the presence of too much of the chiral modifier can cause a decrease in the enantioselectivity of the reaction.{{cite journal | last1 = Heitbaum | first1 = M. | last2 = Glorius | first2 = F. | last3 = Escher | first3 = I. | doi = 10.1002/anie.200504212 | title = Asymmetric Heterogeneous Catalysis | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | volume = 45 | issue = 29 | pages = 4732–62 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16802397| pmc = }} An alternative technique and one that allows more control over the structural and electronic properties of active catalytic sites is the immobilization of catalysts that have been developed for homogeneous catalyis on a heterogeneous support. Covalent bonding of the catalyst to a polymer or other solid support is perhaps most common, though immobilization of the catalyst may also be achieved by [[adsorption]] onto a surface, [[ion exchange]], or even physical encapsulation. One drawback of this approach is the potential for the proximity of the support to change the behaviour of the catalyst, lowering the enantioselectivity of the reaction. To avoid this, the catalyst is often bound to the support by a long linker though cases are known where the proximity of the support can actually enhance the performance of the catalyst. The final approach involves the construction of MOFs that incorporate chiral reaction sites from a number of different components, potentially including chiral and achiral organic ligands, structural metal ions, catalytically active metal ions, and/or preassembled catalytically active organometallic cores.{{cite journal | last1 = Yoon | first1 = M. | last2 = Srirambalaji | first2 = R. | last3 = Kim | first3 = K. | doi = 10.1021/cr2003147 | title = Homochiral Metal–Organic Frameworks for Asymmetric Heterogeneous Catalysis | journal = Chemical Reviews | volume = 112 | issue = 2 | pages = 1196–1231 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22084838| pmc = }} This field is relatively new, and few examples exist of chiral asymmetric hydrogenation using these frameworks. One of these was reported in 2003, when a heterogeneous catalyst was reported that included structural [[zirconium]], catalytically active [[ruthenium]], and a [[BINAP]]-derived [[phosphonate]] as both chiral ligand and structural linker. As little as 0.005 mol% of this catalyst proved sufficient to achieve the asymmetric hydrogenation of aryl ketones, though the usual conditions featured 0.1 mol % of catalyst and resulted in an [[enantiomeric excess]] of 90.6–99.2%.{{cite journal | last1 = Hu | first1 = A. | last2 = Ngo | first2 = H. L. | last3 = Lin | first3 = W. | doi = 10.1021/ja0348344 | title = Chiral Porous Hybrid Solids for Practical Heterogeneous Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Aromatic Ketones | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 125 | issue = 38 | pages = 11490–11491 | year = 2003 | pmid = 13129339| pmc = }} [[File:ZrPhosphonate Heterogeneous Catalyst for Asymmetric Hydrogenation of Aryl Ketones.png|center|200px]]
{{center|The active site of a heterogeneous zirconium phosphonate catalyst for asymmetric hydrogenation}} == Industrial applications == [[File:(S,S)-4 Ro 67-8867.tif|thumb|150px|(''S,S'')-Ro 67-8867]] Knowles' research into asymmetric hydrogenation and its application to the production scale synthesis of L-Dopa gave asymmetric hydrogenation a strong start in the industrial world. More recently, a 2001 review indicated that asymmetric hydrogenation accounted for 50% of production scale, 90% of pilot scale, and 74% of bench scale catalytic, enantioselective processes in industry, with the caveat that asymmetric catalytic methods in general were not yet widely used.{{cite journal | last1 = Blaser | first1 = H. U. | last2 = Spindler | first2 = F. | last3 = Studer | first3 = M. | title = Enantioselective catalysis in fine chemicals production | doi = 10.1016/S0926-860X(01)00801-8 | journal = Applied Catalysis A: General | volume = 221 | pages = 119 | year = 2001 | pmid = | pmc = }} The success of asymmetric hydrogenation in industry can be seen in a number of specific cases where the replacement of kinetic resolution based methods has resulted in substantial improvements in the process's efficiency. For example, Roche's Catalysis Group was able to achieve the synthesis of (S,S)-Ro 67-8867 in 53% overall yield, a dramatic increase above the 3.5% that was achieved in the resolution based synthesis.{{cite book | editor1-last = Blaser | editor1-first = Hans-Ulrich | editor2-first = Hans-Jürgen | editor2-last = Federsel | doi = 10.1002/9783527630639 | title = Asymmetric Catalysis on Industrial Scale |publisher=Wiley-VCH |location=Weinheim | year = 2010 | isbn = 978-3-527-63063-9 | pages = 13–16 }} Roche's synthesis of [[mibefradil]] was likewise improved by replacing resolution with asymmetric hydrogenation, reducing the step count by three and increasing the yield of a key intermediate to 80% from the original 70%.{{cite book |title=Comprehensive Asymmetric Catalysis |last1= |first1= |authorlink1= |vauthors= |editor1-last=Jacobsen |editor1-first=E.N. |editor1-link= |editor2-last=Pfaltz |editor2-first=Andreas |editor2-link= |editor3-last=Yamamato |editor3-first=H. |editor3-link= |year=1999 |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin; New York |isbn=3-540-64336-2 |url= |page= |pages=1443–1445 |ref= }} [[File:Partial Roche Synthesis of Mibefradil.tif|center|700px]]

The '''Barsanti-Matteucci engine''' was the first [[internal combustion engine]]. In late 1851 or early 1852 [[Eugenio Barsanti]], a professor of [[mathematics]], and [[Felice Matteucci]], an [[engineer]] and expert in [[mechanics]] and [[hydraulics]], joined forces on a project to exploit the [[explosion]] and [[Thermal expansion|expansion]] of a gaseous mix of [[hydrogen]] and atmospheric air to transform part of the energy of such explosions into [[mechanical energy]].
==Origin== The idea originated almost ten years earlier with Barsanti when, as a young man, he was teaching at St. Michael's College in [[Volterra]], Italy. An engineer from [[Milan]] Italy, Luigi de Cristoforis, described in a paper published in the acts of the Lombard Royal Institute of Science, Literature and Art, a pneumatic machine (later built and shown to work) that ran on [[naphtha]] and an air mixture, and which constituted the first liquid fuel engine.
==Prototypes== During the twelve years of collaboration between Barsanti and Matteucci several prototypes of [[internal combustion engine]]s were realized. It was the first real internal combustion engine,<ref>http://www.barsantiematteucci.it/inglese/index.asp</ref> constituted in its simplest realization by a vertical cylinder in which an explosion of a mixture of [[air]] and [[hydrogen]] or an [[illuminating gas]] shot a [[piston]] upwards thereby creating a [[vacuum]] in the space underneath. When the piston returned to its original position, due to the action of the [[atmospheric pressure]], it turned a toothed rod connected to a [[sprocket]] wheel and transmitted movement to the driving shaft.
==Patents== Numerous [[patent]]s were obtained by the two [[inventor]]s: the 1854 English<ref>http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/originalDocument?CC=GB&NR=185701655A&KC=A&FT=D&ND=3&date=18571201&DB=EPODOC&locale=en_EP</ref> and Piedmont patents, the 1861 Piedmont patent of Barsanti, Matteucci and Babacci which was then used as a base to construct the engine of the [[Escher Wyss & Cie.|Escher Wyss]] company of [[Zurich]] and put on exhibit during the first National Expo of Florence in 1861, and the 1861 English patent.

Shown below are the CNG storage tanks in the trunk.]]
'''Bi-fuel vehicles''' are [[vehicle]]s with [[multifuel]] engines capable of running on two fuels. On [[internal combustion engine]]s one [[fuel]] is [[gasoline]] or [[Diesel fuel|diesel]], and the other is an [[alternative fuel vehicles|alternate fuel]] such as [[Compressed natural gas|natural gas (CNG)]], [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]], or [[Hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorpoint.com.au/ffv-alternative.asp|title=Flexible Fuel Vehicles|publisher=Motopoint|author=Diane Nassy|date=|accessdate=2008-08-24|language=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723024113/http://motorpoint.com.au/ffv-alternative.asp|archivedate=23 July 2008|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time in some cases, in others both fuels are used in unison. Bi-fuel vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from gasoline or diesel to the other fuel, manually or automatically.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www11.zetatalk.com/docs/Biogas/Biofuel_Technology_Handbook_Version2_D5_2008.pdf| title=Glossary| author=| publisher=Biofuel Marketplace Project| date=| accessdate=2014-12-21| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915032335/http://www8.zetatalk.com/docs/Biogas/Biofuel_Technology_Handbook_Version2_D5_2008.pdf| archivedate=2012-09-15| df=}} See Glossary for definition of Bi-fuel Vehicle</ref><ref name="Handbook">{{cite web | url=http://www.compete-bioafrica.net/publications/publ/BioFuel_Technology_Handbook_1vs_WIP.pdf | title=BioFuel Technology Handbook | author=Dominik Rutz and Rainer Jansen | publisher=WIP Renewable Energies |date=February 2007 | accessdate= 2008-09-01 | format= PDF |language= | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080820162321/http://www.compete-bioafrica.net/publications/publ/BioFuel_Technology_Handbook_1vs_WIP.pdf| archivedate= 20 August 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} See definition in Glossary and Abbreviations</ref><ref name="Greenfleet">{{cite web|url=http://www.sugre.info/tools.phtml?id=686 |title=Definition of Terms |author= |publisher=Sustainable Green Fleets |date= |accessdate=2008-09-01 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721235145/http://www.sugre.info/tools.phtml?id=686 |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biofuelmarketplace.com/(S(mfsz0yfocwuc4lbg2lkdidel))/Anonym/Glossary.aspx?Letter=5 |title=Glossary |author= |publisher=Biofuel Marketplace |date= |accessdate=2008-09-01 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211201822/http://www.biofuelmarketplace.com/%28S%28mfsz0yfocwuc4lbg2lkdidel%29%29/Anonym/Glossary.aspx?Letter=5 |archivedate=December 11, 2008 |df= }} See definition of FFV</ref>
The most common technology and alternate fuel available in the market for bi-fuel gasoline cars is [[Liquefied petroleum gas|Autogas (LPG)]], followed by [[Compressed natural gas|natural gas (CNG)]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eere.energy.gov/afdc/vehicles/natural_gas.html | title=Natural Gas Vehicles | author=Alternative Fuels and Advanced Vehicles Data Center | publisher=US Department of Energy | date= | accessdate=2008-09-01 |language= | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080901201306/http://www.eere.energy.gov/afdc/vehicles/natural_gas.html| archivedate= 1 September 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and it is used mainly in Europe. The Netherlands and the Baltic states have a large number of cars running with LPG. [[Italy]] currently has the largest number of CNG vehicles, followed by Sweden. They are also used in [[South America]], where these vehicles are mainly used as [[taxicab]]s in main cities of [[Brazil]] and [[Argentina]]. Normally, standard gasoline vehicles are retrofitted in specialized shops, which involve installing the [[gas cylinder]] in the trunk and the LPG or CNG injection system and electronics.
==Diesel conversions== Diesel engine is compression ignition engine and does not have spark plug. To operate a diesel engine with an alternate combustible fuel source such as [[Natural gas]], '''Dual-Fuel''' system used. Natural gas as the main fuel while [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] fuel is used for the ignition of the gas/air mixture inside the cylinder (a portion of diesel is injected at the end of the compression stroke, thereby maintaining the original diesel operation principle)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eprints.uthm.edu.my/8473/|title=Conversion method of a diesel engine to a CNG-diesel dual fuel engine and its financial savings|last=Mukhsin|first=Ismail, Muammar|last2=Hakim|first2=Zulkifli, Abd Fathul|date=April 2016|website=eprints.uthm.edu.my|access-date=2018-08-20|last3=Fawzi|first3=Mohd Ali, Mas|last4=Azmir|first4=Osman, Shahrul}}</ref>
Dual fuel operation means the engine uses two fuels (gas and diesel) at the same time, as opposed to Bi Fuel which would mean the engine could have the option of using either fuel separately.
There usually two type of conversions - low speed (below 1000 [[revolutions per minute|RPM]]) and high speed (between 1200 and 1800 RPM).
[[Image:Low speed conversion.jpg|thumb|Low Speed Conversion]]
===Low and middle speed conversion=== Gas is injected into the cylinder inlet manifold by individual gas electromagnetic valves installed as close to the suction valves as possible. The valves are separately timed and controlled by injection control unit. This system interrupts the gas supply to the cylinder during the long overlap of the suction and exhaust valves (just typical for slow-speed and medium-speed engines – within the valve overlap cylinder scavenging is performed). This avoids substantial gas losses and prevents dangerous gas flow to the exhaust manifold.
* This conversion is adjusted for low speed engines up to 1000 RPM. * System for conversion of industrial diesel engine to Bi-fuel operation by substitution of 70-90% natural gas for diesel or HFO. * Gas is injected directly before intake valve by high speed electromagnetic injector, one or two injector per each cylinder.
=== High speed conversion=== [[Image:High speed conversion.jpg|thumb|High Speed Conversion]]
Gas is mixed with air by a common mixer installed before turbocharger(s). Gas flow is controlled by a throttle valve, which is electronically operated by the special control system according to the required engine output and speed. In order to avoid knocking of the engine, knocking detector/controller is installed, thus enabling engine operation at the most efficient gas/diesel ratio.
* Suitable for all High Speed engines, 1200-1800 RPM. * System for conversion of industrial diesel engine to Bi-fuel operation by substitution of 50-80% natural gas for diesel. * Gas and air are blended behind air filter before turbocharger by central mixer. <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iRwH9BF0h1w</ref>
==Common conversion features== {{prose|section|date=March 2017}} * Substantial savings on operation costs * Practically no engine modification required * Non-derated output power * Fuel flexibility: Possibility of bi-fuel or original pure diesel operations * Safe operations. * Lower emissions * Longer engine life span, longer service and maintenance intervals
==Gas types used== It is common to use [[Compressed Natural Gas|CNG (Compressed Natural Gas)]] or [[Liquefied natural gas|LNG (Liquid Natural Gas)]] for bi-fuel operations. Both are also mostly used for [[Electrical generator|Generator sets]] conversions, because the engine does not lose the output power.
In recent years [[biogas]] is being used. The [[biogas]] composition and calorific value must be known in order to evaluate if the particular biogas type is suitable. Calorific value may be an issue as biogas is derived from different sources and there is low calorific value in many cases. You can imagine you have to inject sufficient volume of gas into the cylinder to substitute [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] oil (or, better to say, substitute energy delivered by diesel oil). If the calorific value (energy) of the biogas was very low, there is a need to inject really big volume of biogas into the cylinder, which might be technically impossible. Additionally, the composition of the biogas has to lean towards ignitable gases and be filtered as much as possible of non-combustible compounds such as carbon dioxide.
Associated gas is the last type of gas which is commonly used for bi-fuel conversions of generator sets. Associated gas is a natural gas found in association with oil, either dissolved in the oil or as a cap of free gas above the oil. It means it has almost the same quality as CNG or LNG. <ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/28/halliburton-leads-effort-_n_3342119.html</ref>
==Diesel/gas ratio== It depends on the technical state of the engine, especially of the injection system. The typical Diesel / Gas ratio is 40/60% for the high-speed engines. If the operating output of the engine is constant and between 70-80% of nominal output, than it is possible to reach up to 30/70% ratio.<ref>http://hhpinsight.com/epoperations/2013/02/cummins-for-pge-universal-fracking/</ref> If the operating output is lower (for example 50% of the nominal output) or if there are variations, the rate is about 45/55% (more of diesel is used).For Low Speed conversions it is possible to reach the Diesel/gas ratio up to 10/90%. Generally, it is not possible to guarantee an exact diesel/gas ratio without a test being done after the conversion.

{{advert|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Chip PC Technologies | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{TLV|CPPC}}) | key_people = Dan AMSELLEM ([[CEO]]) | industry = [[Computer Systems]], [[Information Technology|IT]] | products = [[Thin client]]s | revenue = {{profit}} [[New Israeli Shekel|₪]] 42.440 million (''2017'') | operating_income = | net_income = {{profit}} [[New Israeli Shekel|₪]] 2.523 million (''2017'') | num_employees = | divisions = | subsid = Chip PC Technologies GmbH (Germany), Chip PC TEchnologies Inc. (U.S.A.) | foundation = 2000 | location_city = [[Rehovot]] | location_country = [[Israel]] | homepage = }} [[File:WikiAir Flight IL-13-02 1231.JPG|thumbnail|Aerial view of [[Matam, Haifa|Matam Technology park]], location of ChipPC's headquarters]] '''Chip PC Technologies''' is a developer and manufacturer of [[thin client]] [[solution]]s and management software for [[Server (computing)|server-based computing]]; where in a network architecture applications are deployed, managed and can be fully executed on the server.
==History== Chip PC was founded in 2000 by Aviv Soffer and Ora Meir Soffer and raised its first round of financing from R.H. Technologies Ltd. ({{TLV|RHTCH}}), an [[Electronic Contract Manufacturing|electronics contract manufacturing]] group.<ref>{{Citation | title = Chip PC receives first round of funding from R.H. Technologies Ltd | journal = [[The Daily Deal]] -- September 2001 }}</ref>
In 2005 [[Elbit Systems]] acquired 20% of the company.<ref>[http://www.wikinvest.com/stock/Elbit_Systems_(ESLT)/Chip Elbit Systems acquired an approximately 20% interest (18.5% plus a loan convertible into additional shares) in Chip PC Ltd.] ESLT 20-F filed May 28, 2008.</ref>
The company grew rapidly and established partnerships with [[Dell]], which distributes its products, and [[Microsoft]]. In June 2007, it raised [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]] 26 million in stocks, bonds, and warrants in an [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] on the [[Tel Aviv Stock Exchange]].<ref name=Yoshai>{{Citation | title = Chip PC wins thin client computer order | url = http://www.ivc-online.com/ivcWeeklyItem.asp?articleID=6048 | author = Yoshai, Michal | journal = Globes,19-09-2007 -- | accessdate = 2009-11-06 }}</ref>
In November 2007, the company won Europe's largest [[Thin client]] tender thus far, to supply 20,000 Thin client [[Personal computer|PC's]] and management software to RZF, the tax authority of the State of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] in Germany.<ref>{{Citation | title = Chip PC Wins Europe's Largest Thin Client Tender to Supply 20,000 Thin Clients and Management Software to German RZF | url = http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1141921/chip_pc_wins_europes_largest_thin_client_tender_to_supply/index.html | journal = PRNewswire -- 13 November 2007 | accessdate = 2009-11-06 }}</ref>
==Overview== Chip PC supplies thin clients to Multinational & [[Public sector]] organizations, recently winning 1st place in an independent Thin-Clients Evaluation among 26 thin clients from 9 vendors worldwide. Among Chip PC customers are top organizations from various verticals, such as Healthcare, Finance, Defense ([[Israeli Navy]]), Government (US Police), and Education.<ref name=Technologies>{{Citation | title = Company Profile | url = http://www.chippc.com/support/downloads/files/CPN04008_ChipPC_Company_Brochure09-2008.pdf | author = Chip PC Technologies | accessdate = 2009-11-06 }}</ref>
Although the company's main target markets are enterprises and large organizations, it modifies and customizes models to fit other markets; such as the Networked home, [[Small office/home office|SOHO]] (Small-Office-Home-Office), [[Point of sale]] and others.<ref name=Technologies />

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Crystal Decisions''' (previously known as ''[[Seagate Software]] Information Management Group'') was a company that was known for its [[business intelligence]] products.
The company was formed when [[hard disk drive]] manufacturer [[Seagate Technology]] acquired [[Holos#Company|Holistic Systems]] and [[Crystal Services]] with the intention of pursuing better profit margins in the [[software]] market. Holistic Systems had a wide range of sales offices, infrastructure and the [[Holos]] [[OLAP]] product, whilst Crystal Services had good [[OEM]] deals for the [[Crystal Reports]] database reporting product that they had written. The first new product from the combined company was Seagate Info, which later evolved to become known as [[Crystal Enterprise]]. [[Crystal Analysis]] followed as an OLAP client.
The company's structure reflected its heritage, with OLAP technologies being developed out of the former Holistic Systems R&D site in [[Ipswich]], [[Suffolk]], [[England]] and Relational Database technologies being developed out of the former Crystal Services R&D centre in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]].
Crystal Decisions was acquired by [[Business Objects (company)|Business Objects]] in December 2003. As part of this acquisition, the former research and development site in [[Ipswich]], [[Suffolk]], [[England]], was closed with a loss of about 80 jobs in order to centralize development in [[Vancouver]] and [[Paris]], with the support for the [[Holos]] product being outsourced to [[Raspberry Software]] based near Ipswich.
The Holos product line has now{{When|date=October 2016}} ceased.
Business Objects was purchased by [[SAP AG|SAP]] in March 2008.
